question: How do I apply for an account?
answer: You can apply for an account at [https://alliancecan.ca/en/services/advanced-research-computing/account-management/apply-account].

question: What should I know about multifactor authentication?
answer: See the [[Multifactor authentication]] documentation.

question: Where can I find answers to common questions about the CCDB?
answer: Consult the [[Frequently Asked Questions about the CCDB]].

question: What information is important for an experienced HPC user logging onto a cluster?
answer: Experienced users should know what systems are available, what software is available and how environment modules work, how to submit jobs, and how the filesystems are organized.

question: How can new HPC users connect to the HPC systems?
answer: New HPC users can read about how to connect to our HPC systems with [[SSH]].

question: Is there an introduction to Linux systems for new HPC users?
answer: Yes, new users can read an [[Linux introduction]] to Linux systems.

question: How do I transfer files to and from the HPC systems?
answer: New HPC users can read about how to [[Transferring data|transfer files]] to and from our systems.

question: Are there discipline-specific guides available?
answer: Yes, guides are available for AI and Machine Learning, Bioinformatics, Biomolecular simulation, Computational chemistry, Computational fluid dynamics (CFD), Geographic information systems (GIS), and Visualization.

question: What service is recommended for moving hundreds of gigabytes of data across the network?
answer: For moving hundreds of gigabytes of data, read about the [[Globus]] file transfer service.

question: How can Python users install modules in a virtual environment?
answer: Python users can learn how to [[Python#Creating_and_using_a_virtual_environment|install modules in a virtual environment]].

question: How can R users install packages?
answer: R users can learn how to [[R|install packages]].

question: Where can I find resources for software that doesn't run well on traditional HPC clusters?
answer: Read about [[Cloud|our cloud resources]] if you want to experiment with software that doesn’t run well on traditional HPC clusters.

question: How can I get help for other questions not covered in the documentation?
answer: You can try the Search box, the main page for [[Technical documentation]], or [[Technical support|contact us]] by email.

question: Which HPC systems are available for access?
answer: You can request access to Arbutus, Fir, Narval, Nibi, Rorqual, and Trillium.

question: When were the new national systems installed or upgraded?
answer: Four systems were installed in 2025, while one was upgraded.

question: What type of system is Arbutus?
answer: Arbutus is a cloud site, which allows users to launch and customize virtual machines.

question: How can I obtain access to Arbutus?
answer: See [[Cloud]] for how to obtain access to Arbutus.

question: Which systems are considered general-purpose clusters?
answer: Fir, Narval, Nibi, and Rorqual are general-purpose clusters.

question: What are the characteristics of the general-purpose clusters like Fir, Narval, Nibi, and Rorqual?
answer: These are general-purpose clusters composed of a variety of nodes including large memory nodes and nodes with accelerators such as GPUs. You can log into any of these using [[SSH]].

question: How is the term 'cluster' defined in this documentation?
answer: In this documentation, “cluster” reflects the architecture where a large number of individual computers, or “nodes,” are linked together as a unit.

question: What is Trillium designed for?
answer: Trillium is a homogeneous cluster designed for large parallel jobs (>1000 cores).

question: What credentials do I use to log into the new national systems?
answer: Your password is the same one you use to log into [https://ccdb.alliancecan.ca/ CCDB], and your username will be displayed at the top of the page once you've logged in.

question: Who organizes the HPC training workshops?
answer: Most workshops are organized by the Alliance's regional partners.

question: What types of training opportunities are available?
answer: Both online and in-person training opportunities exist on a wide variety of subjects and at different levels of sophistication.

question: Where can I find training resources from WestDRI?
answer: You can consult the [https://training.westdri.ca Training Materials website] and the [https://www.ualberta.ca/information-services-and-technology/research-computing/bootcamps.html UAlberta ARC Bootcamp].

question: What training resources does SHARCNET provide?
answer: SHARCNET offers a [https://www.sharcnet.ca/my/news/calendar Training Events Calendar], a [http://youtube.sharcnet.ca/ YouTube Channel], and [https://training.sharcnet.ca/ Online Workshops].

question: How can I access SciNet's educational resources?
answer: SciNet has an [https://education.scinet.utoronto.ca SciNet Education Site] and a [https://www.youtube.com/c/SciNetHPCattheUniversityofToronto SciNet YouTube Channel].

question: What training information is available from Calcul Québec?
answer: Calcul Québec provides information on [https://calculquebec.eventbrite.ca/ Workshops] and general [https://www.calculquebec.ca/en/academic-research-services/training/ Training information].

question: Where can I find ACENET's training resources?
answer: ACENET offers [https://www.ace-net.ca/training.html Training information] and an [https://www.youtube.com/@ACENETDRI ACENET YouTube Channel].

question: Is there a unified calendar for upcoming training events?
answer: Yes, one can find a shared calendar of [https://alliancecan.ca/en/services/advanced-research-computing/technical-support/training-calendar upcoming workshops].

question: Who should I contact if I need help deciding which HPC system to use?
answer: If the system descriptions are insufficient, contact our [[technical support]].

question: What specific details might technical support ask for when helping me choose a system?
answer: They may ask about the software you want to use (e.g., commercial license, non-interactive, Linux compatible), resource requirements, and job frequency.

question: What if I don't know the answers to technical support's questions about system choice?
answer: Our technical support team is there to help you find the answers and direct you to the most appropriate resources for your needs.
